Questions.QuestionString: What is the aim of Human factors?
Answers: Define the methods to find out and punish the rule violated person
Find the human errors and correct them

Optimize human performance within a system by contributing to the planning, design, and evaluation of tasks, jobs, products, organizations, environments and systems in order to make them compatible with the needs, abilities, and limitations of people.

Questions.QuestionString: What is reporting culture?
Answers: Those who manage and operate system have current knowledge that determine the safety of the system as a whole.
An organization is able to  learn from its mistakes and make changes.
A culture environment where people have confidence to report their error or safety concerns.

Questions.QuestionString: What does informed culture mean?
Answers: A culture environment where people have confidence to report their error or safety concerns.
Those who manage and operate system have current knowledge that determine the safety of the system as a whole.
An organization is able to  learn from its mistakes and make changes.

Questions.QuestionString: What does learning culture mean?
Answers: Those who manage and operate system have current knowledge that determine the safety of the system as a whole.
An organization is able to  learn from its mistakes and make changes.
A culture in which an organization is able to reconfigure themselves in the face of high tempo operations or certain kinds of danger.

Questions.QuestionString: Which factors cause fatigue?
Answers: Number of days worked, time off between shifts, time off between duty blocks, overtime, long-haul flights.
Sleep disorders, exercise, nutrition, domestic responsibilities, social commitments, sleep need.

Questions.QuestionString: Which of the following is a common complaint linked with working non-standard hours (e.g. night shift)?
Answers: Being annoyed or in bad mood after not sleeping enough.
Being too focused on one thing and losing situation awareness (i.e. what is happening around you).

Questions.QuestionString: What are elements of safety culture?
Answers: Reporting culture, informed culture, flexible culture, learning culture, organization culture
Informed culture, reporting culture, just culture, learning culture, flexible culture
Learning culture, just culture, informed culture, reporting culture, positive culture

Human Factors is a scientific discipline concerned with
Answers: Adjustments of human capacities to machine requirements
Understanding of interactions between the human and the system

Questions.QuestionString: The meaning of “Event Iceberg” ?
Answers: All events are due to similar contributing factors. Therefore, responding to lower level events will prevent higher level events.
Anything that can go wrong will go wrong
All events are due to similar contributing factors. Therefore, responding to higher level events will prevent lower level events.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Fatigue?
Answers: A state of physical performance impairment, which can impair the ability to perform safely.
A state of mental performance impairment, which can impair alertness.
A state of physical performance and mental performance impairment, which can impair the ability and alertness to perform safely.

Questions.QuestionString: Which of the following statements is correct?
Answers: To prevent accidents or incidents I report all failures or anomalies I have encountered.
Drinking alcohol increase professional competency and skill.
Long-term effects of caffeine are boost your memory and alertness.

Questions.QuestionString: What causes ineffective leadership?
Definitions of Error?
Answers: A human action (behavior) that unintentionally departs from the expected action (behavior).
A human action (behavior) that intentionally departs from the expected action (behavior).

Questions.QuestionString: What is Lack of Awareness?
Answers: Not having the knowledge, skill or experience to do the job.
Failure to recognize a situation, understand what it is, and predict the possible results.
Passing on to others your meaning and intent.

Questions.QuestionString: Visual Inspection means inspection using either or all of human senses such as :
Common aircraft visual inspections include:
Answers: system inspections, structural inspections, and zonal inspections
system inspections, electrical inspections, and zonal inspections

Questions.QuestionString: Choose correct answer:
Answers: Over 80% of inspections on aircraft are visual inspections, which are often the most economical and fastest way to find defects on an aircraft.
Over 85% of inspections on aircraft are visual inspections, which are often the most economical and fastest way to find defects on an aircraft.
Over 90% of inspections on aircraft are visual inspections, which are often the most economical and fastest way to find defects on an aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: Common error capturing tasks
Answers: Operational/functional checks, Mechanic/pilot pre-flight walk around checks,Task inspections/duplicate inspections
Operational/functional checks, Mechanic pre-flight walk around checks. Task inspections/duplicate inspections
Operational/functional checks, Pilot pre-flight walk around checks. Task inspections/duplicate inspections
